title: Task Force on Enterprise Interoperability Science Base
segmentation: Asthma Kelly said we originally thought we only had this morning, so my presentation is potentially very short indeed.
'cause I was planning on taking two or three minutes, but I still think everybody who's here.

Is necessarily knows about interrupt the lab itself, so I ought to mention little bit about that interrupt the lab was set up out of the interrupt network of excellence funded by the Commissioning Framework Program.
I would get confused as its continuation into the future and does a fairly wide range of things now it has.
A membership across Europe and wider than that and its purpose is to keep together the community community of researchers and practitioners who were involved in.
Enterprise interoperability research in Framework Program 6 and before, and to carry that on into the future.
What we've done with.
Find a way going forward on this.
I was lucky.
What we've done within interrupt the lab is to set up a set of task forces which are associated with the various areas of research that Interop has.
Taking an interest in Caesars relevant to enterprise interoperability are one of those is the science based tax course.
But of course what you'll see fairly clearly.
I hope from the slide is that there's beginning to be a group of bodies working in this area.
The first one that was formally set up was the.
Cluster.
Defines cluster future Internet and enterprise systems cluster used to be the AEI.

Cluster with organized by the Commission and that originally was the one that Kristina mentioned which started up about a year and a bit ago, then again sponsored by the Commission is the expert group which is which was developed over the last few months and met for the first time a couple of weeks ago.
And then now we've got yet another task force within interrupt Villa.
And what we don't.
We're not trying to do is to set up all these in competition with each other.
We hope that they're going to work together.
I certainly do.
'cause I had the slightly odd position I'm involved in all three one way or another, and if they start competing with each other, I'm going to have some serious problems.
So what we see is the what I see.
Maybe everybody else has got different ideas and will throw things at me.
But what I see is that these bodies are small groups initially with interests in getting input from the wider community.

Interrupt the lab is part of that wider community and I see the role of the task force not as trying to duplicate or compete with anything that's going on up there, but to provide a route to the partnership that interrupt the lab represents.
And.
That is quite a big partnership.
There are the way interrupt the lab is set up.

There are eight regional polls in different geographical areas, which range from the Southwest of France to the northwest of China, northeast of China, mainly European polls, but the Chinese pool was an exception there.
Across those at the last count, there are 76 partners.
Partners are individual institutions or companies involved as part of one of the regional polls, and they represent at least 300 researchers and practitioners.
Probably more because we tend to count them conservatively as one per partner.
Unless we've got more information, so we're probably talking between 3 and 500 real people out there who have an interest in what we're doing, so it's a big constituency.
And the reason that's perhaps important is that.
As I say, my view of the role of.
The Villain Task Force is to provide expert input to the.
Cluster Taskforce, the expert group.
If we can't do that, there's something seriously wrong because we have so many experts in the field involved.

We give a route for those bodies to actually disseminate back to the Community again, reaching a wide range of people so that we can pick up comment and contributions there, and one of the things which interrupt the lab inherited from the network of excellence, which it's now developed on and is enhancing as we speak our knowledge map and a knowledge repository for work that's being developed in the field of enterprise interoperability and associated with that field.
Over the past eight to nine years, so there is a wide body of knowledge and experience there which can be available through interop to the clusters.
The expert group, and so on.
So that's where the fines test the lab Taskforce fits in, not in competition.
It's not done a lot that's independent from those other areas because we work with them.
As I say, I'm a member in one form or other of both those other groups, so.
Tend to be involved in those and the other reason is that we've only recently set up this task force structure within Interop V Lab in response to some of these initiatives.
So that was all I was going to say.
Happy to take local questions or.
Move on to the afternoon.
Or if anybody thinks I've got it completely wrong, they can tell me as well.
What exactly is the input of these?
We left the scores will bring to the two other groups.
Completely speaking, I mean, what do you envisage?

Concretely speaking we already have a lot of links to the various disciplines that have been involved in enterprise interoperability, including those that are associated with other science spaces such as complex systems, model driven architectures, and so on.
So there is a lot of knowledge about the work that's been done on.
An enterprise interoperability in the past which must feed into the content of the Sciencebase must feed into the categorization of what constitutes the science space as an example.
There is a lot of understanding being developed by partners.
In their own projects within interrupt the lab which is fed back through the knowledge base which is available to the expert groups on the clusters as they go.
Definition of the domain will not necessarily come from the dashboard.
Show from the clusters Task Force or the expert group, and we've got essentially three bodies who are taking an interest.
No one of those, to my knowledge, is said we are going to produce the ultimate answer.
I think they're working together and they bring different things to the party, so to speak, so.
What Ivy that brings to the party is a very big community and a communication set of communication routes.
Because of the structure of poles and partners and individuals, we can actually contact people and get responses.
On most issues, relatively quickly and effectively if we've got a reasonable question to ask and we can ask them to do things to respond or to provide input we have in the past.
In your opinion, what would be the next step with, let's say, next?
Task Force will produce between here the finest defines task force, I think what?
We have at the moment which is coming to fruition is the paper which Janice has been working on, which provides.
From my memory of it, a structure that we could work with in.
I think we need to put that together with the report which you said is coming from the expert group and saying what is the way forward.
How do we actually define a structure now?
What will be in it that then needs disseminating to the community for people to say?
Yet these things should be in it?
Why's that there?
Perhaps it shouldn't be.
What about these things that aren't there that should be in it?
And I think that's where the feedback to the Community has some benefit, because if we produce a science based switch.
Is perhaps.
Logically consistent, logically elegant, but which nobody else contributes to.
It's not very much use.
We want to want something which carries a consensus of opinion in the practicing community, I think.
And unless we manage that feedback, then that won't happen.
OK, so thank you again.
